citation.article-title: Rhodothermus marinus, gen. nov., a thermophilic, halophilic bacterium from submarine hot springs in Iceland

p.s: Rhodothermus (Rho. do. ther'mus, Gr. n. rhodon rose; Gr. fem. n. therme heat; M.L. masc. n. Rhodothermus the red thermophile.)
Cells are Gram-negative, non-motile straight rods with curved ends, about 2-2.5 μm long and 0.5 μm wide, occurring singly.
A slime capsule is formed on carbohydrate-rich medium.
Colonies are reddish-coloured, low convex, 3-4 mm in diameter with an entire edge.
No dissimilatory nitrate reduction and no casein hydrolysis.
Growth on most common sugars like glucose, sucrose, and lactose but not on most amino acids.
Cells are sensitive to penicillin, erythromycin, tetracycline and chloramphenicol, and resistant to streptomycin, kanamycin and gentamicin.
The DNA base composition is about 65 mol % GC.
The type species is Rhodothermus marinus, DSM 4252 (ATCC 43812).
